description: Source Registry — tracks what sources have been scanned and through when. Updated at end of each Phase 1 research session. Check scannedThrough before scanning to avoid duplicate work.

sources.name: Cheeky Pint
sources.scannedThrough: Dario Amodei + Satya Nadella episodes (triaged full episode list). No new eps since Nov 25, 2025 (on hiatus).
sources.notes: Founder-level AI strategy conversations. On hiatus since Nov 2025. Rich source — Greg Brockman, Des Traynor, Kyle Vogt episodes still need deep-scan.

sources.name: No Priors
sources.scannedThrough: Through Sunday Robotics episode (~Jan 2026)
sources.notes: Best startup vs. incumbent coverage. Sunday Robotics ep medium priority for deep-scan.

sources.name: BG2 Pod
sources.scannedThrough: Triaged through Open-Source Models/Compute Arms Race ep (~Feb 2026). New eps since Dec 23: AI Bubble/Stablecoin, Tariffs/Export Controls, AI Diffusion Rule, Michael Dell, Open-Source Models. All macro except Michael Dell (HIGH for deep-scan).
sources.notes: Tier-1 VC view on AI CapEx. HIGH deep-scan backlog: Satya Nadella + Sam Altman ep, OpenAI CPO Kevin Weil ep, Michael Dell ep.

sources.name: Dwarkesh Podcast
sources.scannedThrough: Full list triaged; Nadella (Nov 12) + Sutskever (Nov 25) deep-scanned. No 2026 eps yet.
sources.notes: Deep technical + scaling debates. Nadella + Sutskever deep-scanned. Still pending: Andrej Karpathy (Oct 17).

sources.name: Latent Space
sources.scannedThrough: Episode list triaged through Jan 2026 (Glean/Windsurf, World Labs, OpenAI Codex)
sources.notes: AI engineer + application layer. Glean enterprise AI episode is high-value for deep scan.

sources.name: Acquired
sources.scannedThrough: Full episode list triaged through NFL 2026 Update (Jan 26, 2026). Google AI Company (Oct 5) + Taylor/Bavor (Aug 18) deep-scanned.
sources.notes: Definitive company histories. COMPLETED deep-scans: Google: The AI Company (Oct 5), Bret Taylor + Clay Bavor (Aug 18). REMAINING HIGH: Alphabet Inc (Aug 26). MEDIUM: Tobi Lutke/Shopify, Jamie Dimon, Coca-Cola.

sources.name: Conversations with Tyler
sources.scannedThrough: Triaged recent AI eps; Jack Clark/Anthropic (Ep 242, May 2025) deep-scanned; Mercor/Brendan Foody (Oct 2025) noted; 2025 Year-in-Review noted.
sources.notes: Macro AI + talent dynamics. Jack Clark ep is highest-value for Anthropic culture/org. Mercor ep relevant for workforce restructuring thesis.

sources.name: Invest Like the Best
sources.scannedThrough: Triaged through Ep 454 (Mar 2025 release). Ep 451 Gavin Baker (Dec 16, 2025) and Ep 450 David George/a16z (Dec 9, 2025) are high/medium priority for deep-scan. Ep 452 Ellenbogen (Jan 6, 2026) medium. Ep 453 Hastings low.
sources.notes: Deep tech founders, investors. Gavin Baker ep highest priority — Nvidia v. Google, AI economics, SaaS mistakes. David George/a16z ep covers Databricks, OpenAI, Cursor, Harvey.

sources.name: The Cognitive Revolution
sources.scannedThrough: Triaged recent eps; Atlassian/Sherif Mansour (Nov 20, 2025) deep-scanned. AI 2025→2026 Live Show (Parts 1+2) noted. Daniel Miessler, Illia Polosukhin eps noted.
sources.notes: AI agents, operational deep dives. Atlassian ep is highest-value for enterprise AI org structure (Teamwork Graph, Rovo agents). AI 2025→2026 Live Show mostly macro/policy.

sources.name: All-In Podcast
sources.notes: VC perspective, market dynamics

sources.name: Lex Fridman Podcast
sources.notes: Long-form AI researcher interviews

sources.name: Stratechery
sources.scannedThrough: Through Jan 31, 2026. 'Chip Fly in AI Ointment' + 'Technology Doings' (Jan 15-31) — macro AI infra, no org-specific specimens.
sources.notes: Big Tech AI strategy. Most content is paywalled. Key 2026 articles: Meta Compute, AI Power. Integration/modularization framework highly relevant. Jan 15-31 content was macro chip/infra analysis.

sources.name: One Useful Thing
sources.scannedThrough: Through Jan 31, 2026. No new org-structural posts since Jan 7 (capability-focused posts only). Making AI Work (May 2025) most relevant recent org post.
sources.notes: How work is changing. Reshaping the Tree is foundational for org restructuring framing. Making AI Work (May 2025) covers Leadership/Lab/Crowd model. Jan 2026 posts are AI-capability focused, not org-structural.

sources.name: Not Boring
sources.scannedThrough: Searched; no 2026 AI org articles found via site search
sources.notes: AI + hard tech. No relevant AI org structure articles found in Jan 2026 search. May need to search McCormick's X/LinkedIn for recent takes.

sources.name: The Generalist
sources.scannedThrough: Searched through Jan 2026. Future 50 (Aug 2025) most relevant. No AI org structure articles found.
sources.notes: Company deep dives. Low relevance for core research question — focuses on startup profiles and VC, not org structure. Monitor monthly.

sources.name: Import AI
sources.scannedThrough: Searched through Jan 2026. Macro AI trends (PostTrainBench, AI Economy divergence). No org-specific specimens.
sources.notes: AI policy & research. Covers macro trends, not org structure. Monitor for policy changes affecting governance roles (e.g., EU AI Act compliance).

sources.name: The Pragmatic Engineer
sources.scannedThrough: Triaged 2025-2026 articles. AI Engineering Stack, AI Engineering in Real World, 2025 year-in-review scanned. Pragmatic Summit (Feb 11, 2026) noted. No org-specific specimens but strong macro signal on AI-native team structures.
sources.notes: Engineering org restructuring, AI tooling impact on teams, layoff structural analysis. High signal for how engineering orgs are actually changing day-to-day. Partially paywalled. Key trends: Senior-Only model, AI Reliability Engineer role, Talent Hollow. Pragmatic Summit Feb 11 2026 may yield org-specific data.

sources.name: LinkedIn Economic Graph / LinkedIn News
sources.scannedThrough: Keyword search for CAIO appointments through Feb 1, 2026. Surfaced UBS Magazzeni, CBA Boteju, Stagwell Kahan appointments via cross-references. Ad agency CAIO wave (Monks, IPG, Stagwell).
sources.notes: Primary source for CAIO appointments, AI role growth data, executive moves. Track via keyword searches (CAIO, Head of AI, AI reorg). Also linkedin.com/news for editorial takes on workforce shifts.

sources.name: Lenny's Newsletter
sources.notes: Product management perspective on AI product orgs, team structure, hiring. More tactical than structural but occasionally covers org design.

sources.name: Elad Gil's Blog
sources.notes: AI company scaling, org design at growth stage. Overlaps with No Priors podcast. Sporadic posting but high-quality when published.

sources.name: Platformer
sources.notes: Big Tech internal reorgs, culture shifts, leadership changes. More policy/moderation focused but covers major structural changes at Meta, Google, etc.

sources.name: State of AI Report
sources.host: Nathan Benaich & Ian Hogarth (Air Street Capital)
sources.notes: Comprehensive annual report. Covers AI talent flows, lab dynamics, governance trends. Oct 2025 edition likely has org-relevant data.

sources.name: The Decoder
sources.notes: AI researcher departures, lab dynamics, talent moves. Discovered during substacks/BG2 session. Good for tracking explore/execute personnel shifts.

sources.name: Harvard Business Review (AI)
sources.scannedThrough: Scanned Jan 29, 2026 article 'Companies Are Laying Off Workers Because of AI's Potential—Not Its Performance' (Davenport & Srinivasan). Macro trend piece, no org-specific specimens.
sources.notes: Authoritative AI org structure pieces. Slow cadence but high-credibility. Jan 29 article by Davenport/Srinivasan is key citation for 'potential vs. performance' layoff paradox. Partially paywalled.

sources.name: Wall Street Journal
sources.scannedThrough: Headline triage via web search through Feb 1, 2026. Paywalled — limited free results. No new org-specific specimens beyond what's captured via other sources.
sources.notes: Primary source for major reorg announcements, CEO strategy interviews, earnings call analysis with AI restructuring language, CAIO/CTO appointments at Fortune 500. Keyword-searchable archive. Paywalled but headlines/excerpts often suffice for triage. Search: 'chief AI officer', 'AI restructuring', 'AI center of excellence', 'AI layoffs'.

sources.name: Financial Times
sources.scannedThrough: Headline triage via web search through Feb 1, 2026. Paywalled — limited free results. EY CEO Outlook (FT Longitude research) is macro trend. No new org specimens.
sources.notes: Strongest on European/global AI org moves (Siemens, SAP, Roche, Novo Nordisk, UK Gov). Better than WSJ for non-US companies. Also strong on AI governance, board-level AI strategy. Paywalled. Search: 'chief AI officer', 'AI transformation', 'AI governance'.

sources.name: Reuters Business/Tech
sources.scannedThrough: Headline triage via web search through Feb 1, 2026. Amazon 16K layoffs (Jan 2026) widely reported via Reuters wire. No new org specimens beyond existing.
sources.notes: Wire service — often first to report layoffs, reorgs, executive changes. Free access. Already surfaced in prior sessions via Google News. Formalizing as tracked source.

sources.name: Bloomberg Technology
sources.scannedThrough: Headline triage via web search through Feb 1, 2026. Meta 4th AI restructuring, Amazon 14K cuts, OpenAI restructuring — all previously captured. AI productivity gains expected 2026.
sources.notes: Deep enterprise AI coverage, M&A reporting (Scale AI/Meta, lab valuations), workforce data. Mark Gurman for Apple AI org, Brad Stone for Amazon. Paywalled but headlines triage well via Google News.

sources.name: The Information
sources.scannedThrough: Headline triage via web search through Feb 1, 2026. Paywalled. Meta 4th AI restructuring (Aug 2025), OpenAI restructuring, SEC/DOGE AI push. Headlines confirm existing specimens. No new org specimens.
sources.notes: Best insider reporting on AI lab internal dynamics — org charts, team restructuring, talent departures, internal strategy debates. Broke many Meta/Google/OpenAI reorg stories. Heavily paywalled but headlines are high-signal for what to search elsewhere.

sources.name: CNBC
sources.notes: CEO interviews on AI strategy (often video), earnings coverage with AI restructuring angles. Already cited in prior sessions (Citigroup layoffs). Free access. Good for CEO quotes on org changes.

sources.name: Fortune
sources.notes: Fortune 500 AI adoption surveys, CEO AI strategy pieces, CAIO profiles. Already cited in prior sessions (AI layoff wave). Partially free.

sources.name: Wired
sources.notes: Long-form AI lab profiles, culture pieces. Steven Levy's access to Google/DeepMind leadership. Less frequent but high-depth when relevant.

sources.name: MIT Technology Review
sources.notes: AI policy, lab governance, responsible AI org structures. Annual AI 50 list. Good for academic-industry bridge perspectives on AI org design.

sources.name: SEC Filings (10-K, 8-K, Proxy)
sources.notes: Primary source for official org structure changes, executive appointments (8-K), AI risk disclosures, CapEx commitments. Search EDGAR for AI mentions in 10-K risk factors. Proxy statements show board AI committee formation.

sources.name: Earnings Call Transcripts
sources.notes: CEOs describe AI org changes on record. Keyword search for 'restructuring', 'center of excellence', 'chief AI officer', 'agentic'. Q4 2025 / Q1 2026 cycles are highest priority.

sources.name: BCG AI Radar
sources.notes: Annual CEO survey, Trailblazer archetype

sources.name: State of Enterprise AI
sources.notes: Enterprise deployment benchmarks

sources.name: Deloitte Tech Trends
sources.notes: Agentic AI adoption data

sources.name: Mercer Global Talent Trends
sources.scannedThrough: Preliminary findings (Jan 14, 2026) reviewed. Full report expected Feb 2026.
sources.notes: 12K respondents across executives, HR, investors, employees. Key data: AI job loss anxiety 28%→40%, 63% C-suite see work redesign as top ROI, 97% investors penalize non-upskilling firms. Full Feb 2026 report may have org-specific cases.

sources.name: Oxford Economics AI & Labor Research
sources.notes: Key counterpoint source on AI layoff narrative. Research briefing cited by Fortune and HBR suggests firms using AI as cover for routine headcount reductions, not actual worker replacement. Find original report.

sources.name: i4cp (Institute for Corporate Productivity)
sources.notes: Predicts 2026 as year AI becomes 'strategic lever for workforce restructuring' at large companies. Referenced in multiple AI layoff articles. Find original report.
